field_edited_text.value:
The Pros and Cons of Expressways

| I I \ | | B I
R EEEREEEEERERER



buildings at approximately the same level as bedroom windows.
Traffic on the lower level is noisier than that on the top level
since the noise can reverberate between the two decks. The prob-
lem is minimized by using a single level structure, by raising the
structure some distance above bedroom windows, or by increasing
the distance between the structure and the residential buildings.
An expressway designed in this manner with 75-foot to 100-foot
separation from nearby residential buildings and without nearby
access ramps will probably create less noise than a normally busy
adjacent city street.

. Light and Air: An elevated expressway can serve to cut off light

and air from the lower stories of adjacent buildings. This problem
is important for residences, retail trade buildings, and probably
offices. It is of less importance for industrial buildings and of no
importance for warehouses. It is generally of little consequence
if only a corner of a building is in close proximity.

A separation of 30 feet to 40 feet between the expressway and
adjacent buildings will usually be sufficient to minimize this prob-
lem. A somewhat greater distance, say 50 feet to 60 feet, would
probably be desirable if the expressway is double-decked.

. Partial Takings: Properties remaining after clearance for an ex-

pressway can produce a most untidy and unpleasant appearance
which may have a blighting effect on the neighborhood. This
result will not occur when clearance comes up to an existing
street so that the nearest buildings are those facing the opposite
side of the street. The blighting effect is usually most acute when
the expressway runs diagonally across the existing street pattern.
When this happens a great many small triangular pieces of land
are left over, back yards are exposed, and building rows are cut

in the middle.

In some circumstances it is possible that over a period of time
adjacent properties will be rebuilt so as to reflect the existence
of the expressway. In this manner the scars left by the express-
way may ultimately be removed. Such a process often requires,
however, the consolidation and rearrangement of the lots in
question and is not easily accomplished without public action. It
is perhaps not wholly coincidental that several public housing
projects and Renewal Area 4 lie adjacent to Fayette Street which
was widened in 1937, that the Mt. Royal Plaza Renewal Area lies
on both sides of the extension of Howard Street constructed in
1938, and that Renewal Area 7 lies on both sides of Russell Street
widened in 1953.

To minimize the blighting effect of partial takings in heavily
developed areas it is desirable to run expressways between two
parallel streets and to clear all of the land between these streets.
Such an arrangement is also desirable from a traffic point of view
since it facilitates the construction of access ramps at appropriate
points and permits the border streets to be used for the collection
and dispersal of traffic between access points.

Evidence that expressways do not have as great an adverse effect
upon adjacent residential areas as is generally assumed can be obtained
from a study recently conducted by the California Division of Highways /
and reported in California Highways and Public Works for March-April, ’Y
1957. While it might be said that the California Division of Highways
would not be wholly unbiased in conducting such a study, nevertheless
the published report seems to indicate that the investigation was thorough,
conscientious, and objective. The study involved a comparison of sales
prices for houses immediately adjacent to expressways with similar houses
